title: COVID-19: Frontline health workers reveal worst is over but war goes on - The West Australian
content:
WA’s summer Omicron wave may have subsided to a ripple, but with more than 20 people dying every week from the virus and the threat of long COVID looming large, those who have spent years on the frontline say the pandemic is far from over.

Nearly three years since the World Health Organisation declared COVID a pandemic in March 2020, WA hospitals are still treating a steady flow of cases and vulnerable regional communities remain very much alert to the danger. Some say it could be years until a “new normal” is established.

title: Nancy Jane Newhouse Leffler Obituary - The Indianapolis Star - IndyStar
content:
Nancy Jane Newhouse Leffler, lifetime nurse and caring mother & grandmother, passed away on February 9, 2023 at the age of 87. Nancy was born in Indianapolis on November 6, 1935, to George and Wanda Newhouse. She attended Broad Ripple High School, Miami University and graduated from Indiana University’s School of Nursing. Nancy worked in the OR, labor and delivery and retired after more than 25 years as a psychiatric nurse at Larue Carter Hospital. She was a tireless volunteer giving her time to Gennesaret Mobile Medical Clinic, Lawrence Township Schools tutoring, Indianapolis Public Library, Indpls Zoo/White River Gardens, Lawrence North High School, & Northminster Presbyterian Church. Nancy was a dedicated mother, avid gardener, dog lover, and walker. Over many decades, neighbors grew to enjoy watching for and greeting Nancy as she walked her dogs every morning and evening. Even while working full time, Nancy always valued family dinners while her children were growing up and took pride in the revelation her son Randy had when he went to school and discovered that kids had cookies that came from the store not their mother’s oven. Grammy was a constant fixture in the stands at every sporting event of her grandchildren. Nancy is preceded in death by her husband of 42 years Truman Leffler, and her sister, Janeane (Donald) Abbitt. She is survived by her brother George “Bud” Newhouse, children George “Randy” (Kim) Leffler of Fishers, and Meri (Adam) Weber of Indianapolis, and 4 grandchildren: Christian Leffler, Kendal (Matt) Speer, Cade Weber, & Cole Weber. Visitation will be held on Friday February 17 from 12:30-2:00 pm with a celebration of her life immediately following at Northminster Presbyterian Church, 1660 Kessler Blvd E Dr, Indianapolis, 46220. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Nancy’s honor to Northminster, the Humane Society of Indianapolis, or the American Heart Association. Leppert Mortuary - Nora Chapel assisting with arrangements. To share a memory, please visit www.leppertmortuary.com

Posted online on February 11, 2023 Published in The Indianapolis Star

title: Curiosity Just Found its Strongest Evidence of Ancient Water and Waves on Mars - Universe Today
content:
This week, NASA’s Curiosity rover stumbled across the best evidence yet that liquid water once covered much of Mars in the planet’s distant past: undulating rippled rock formations – now frozen in time – that were sculpted by the waves of an ancient shallow lake. But perhaps the biggest surprise is that they were discovered in an area that researchers expected to be dry.

NASA’s Curiosity rover has been exploring Gale crater on Mars since 2014, studying the geologic history of the region and assessing whether the planet could ever have supported an environment suitable for organic life. Starting from the crater floor, the rover has been slowly climbing the foothills of Mount Sharp, the five-kilometer-tall central peak at the heart of Gale crater. As it climbs, it traverses Mars’ geologic history. The lower rock layers at the bottom of the crater represent the oldest periods in Mars’ history, and as it climbs higher it is able to study more and more recent deposits.

The ripples discovered this week were found in a region nicknamed the “Marker Band”, which sits about 800 meters above the crater floor. From orbit, the Marker Band looks dark in color, standing out from the slopes of Mount Sharp. It’s well above the region where scientists expected to find evidence of water.

“We climbed through thousands of feet of lake deposits and never saw evidence like this – and now we found it in a place we expected to be dry,” said Ashwin Vasavada, Curiosity’s project scientist at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

A panorama taken by the Curiosity rover on the Maker Band in Gale crater. To the right of the rover, ripples in the rock show evidence of an ancient lakebed. Beneath the rover’s arm, two of Curiosity’s attempted drill-holes can be seen in the rock. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS.

The rocks of the Marker Band contain salty minerals called sulfates, which are usually found in regions where previously wet regions are drying up. But the ripples are clear evidence of sediment stirred up by waves, just like the ripples found in the sand of shallow water beaches here on Earth.

Curiosity is decked out with a suit of geology tools, but two attempts to drill into the Marker Band have been unsuccessful – the rock is too hard to penetrate. Future attempts will be made in the weeks ahead. In the meantime, there are other intriguing formations nearby that tell more of the story.

A mosaic of 17 images captured in the “Marker Band” area by Curiosity’s Mastcam in November 2022, showing regularly repeating layers, likely caused by repetitive, cyclical weather patterns in Mars’ distant past. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS.

Nearby rocks, positioned just above the ripples, feature overlapping layers that are unusually regular in their spacing and thickness. Such regularity suggests a cyclical cause – perhaps repeated weather events or atmospheric phenomena like dust storms. It’s an indication of a period of variable climate conditions at some point in Mars’ history.

Later this year, Curiosity is expected to have a chance to examine debris from a wet landslide in the nearby Gedis Valley, a depression carved partially by wind and partially by a long-vanished river.

This landslide debris is likely to be the most recent water-driven geology in Gale crater, deposited in a period long after the era of liquid lakes.

Gedis Valley, with distant landslide debris on the valley floor. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS.

Taken together, these varied rock formations are helping build a climate timeline for Gale crater. “The wave ripples, debris flows, and rhythmic layers all tell us that the story of wet-to-dry on Mars wasn’t simple. Mars’ ancient climate had a wonderful complexity to it, much like Earth’s,” said Vasavada.

Learn More:

“NASA’s Curiosity Finds Surprise Clues to Mars’ Watery Past.” JPL.

Featured Image: Ripples formed billions of years ago by waves on a shallow lake, imaged by NASA’s Curiosity rover. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS

Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS.
